name: tellumo
text: I completely lost it when I saw this one. The receipt just makes it.

name: tellumo
text: In fact, I may think up a special occasion for which I will go to Safeway and pick up a turkey, a bottle of Christian Brothers, and No-Doz to celebrate. If the bill comes to more than $31.34, I will be annoyed . . . well, ok, I live in San Francisco, so maybe it'll be a little more.

name: unsentletter
text: I'll be getting mine at Church & Market.  Expensive, but 24-hour.

name: chaesar
text:
Yeah man, I guess there weren't no Club Card savings that day.

Wait, can you actually buy hard liquor in a Safeway? Is this a west coast thing?

name: tellumo
text: Yeah, grocery stores in California can sell liquor, beer, and wine. Most Safeway stores do.

name: nighttoad
text: i live in illinois, and it's the same deal here. until i read these comments, i had no idea there was a single grocery store in the country without a liquor section. learn something new every day!

name: bixschmix
text: I envy your naivete.

name: belgand
text: In Kansas the only liquor legal for sale in grocery stores or general convenience stores is 3.2% alcohol beer or equivalent. If you want anything other than "three-two beer" you have to go to a liquor store. No alcohol sales on Sundays either or, IIRC, after 1 or 2 AM. I don't drink so I'm not entirely up on this, but if you live in the Kansas City area it's right on the border with Missouri so you'll get people going over the state line occasionally to take advantage of the more lax laws there.

name: belgand
text: To me the craziest thing was discovering a few years ago with friends that apparently liquor stores are closed on the Fourth of July. At first I thought it was just a few local stores being closed, but it looks like all the ones in my town at the time were. Isn't drinking sort of how the holiday is celebrated though? It made no sense to me.

name: jamb23
text:
Interestingly, 4th July was seen as huge opportunity for temperance in antebellum America: just in the same way that the original Independence Day was freedom from the tyranny of King George, later celebrations emphasised the freedom from the tyranny of "King Alcohol". Apparently at the movement's height in 1844 President Tyler received influential temperance reformers at the White House. So it's probably a remnant from that.

As a history graduate, I find outlets wherever I can.

name: rowboat
text: In regards to liquor laws, I know from personal experience that Oklahoma and Pennsylvania make Kansas seem like a real party state.

name: tekende
text: Oklahoma's liquor laws are about the same as Kansas's, actually, except liquor stores in Kansas close a little late than in Oklahoma.

name: rowboat
text: I've been away from the immediate area for awhile now, but am I incorrect that OK's beer is actually weaker than everywhere else by law?

name: tekende
text: You can get 6.0 at bars and liquor stores. 3.2 at grocery/convenience stores.

name: cpnglxynchos
text: the same is true in Colorado. only beers and Mike's at the supermarkets. the King Soopers (Kroger) closest to me has a liquor store right next door, though. good enough is.

name: belgand
text: Maybe this information for each state should be put on a handy card with age of consent on the back.

name: ohnoadeathray
text: It's the same way in Kentucky, or in most counties around here at least. You can't buy alcohol after 1 AM or on Sundays. We're only about 10 minutes from Indiana though, we can just cross the bridge to get sunday booze.

name: fineoakstructure
text: Wait, you can't buy booze in Indiana on a Sunday, you can't even buy beer - at least, not in stores.

name: saru
text: This isn't about the West Coast either, because both Oregon and Washington prohibit hard alcohol from grocery stores.

name: jlynes
text: Here in Texas, alcohol sales are regulated on a county-by-county basis.  I don't know of any county, though, that allows hard liquor sales outside of liquor stores.  Only beer and wine are available in other locations, and only between certain hours.

name: heccibiggs
text: Here in England, we just sell pretty much any kind of alcohol in all supermarkets all over the country and get on with it. Bad luck, America.

name: rowboat
text: It's like that in most places here in The States, too. We're just highlighting the odd exceptions.

name: kaithekender
text:
Lucky bastards.

I'm from B.C. Grocery stores do not sell liquor. Bars and liquor stores sell liquor.

name: archon_divinus
text: Not entirely true.  Some small town (and we're talking very small) grocery stores have a BC Liquor section.  It's almost run as a separate store though.  You have to pay at a different register and everything, but it's still in the same store.

name: tollschaft
text: I just want to say this has been fascinating to read. Thanks

name: rizzle
text: the GOF is in Bakersfield! hahahahahaha

name: audhumla
text: an astute and appropriate observation

name: xerol
text: The turkey is 8.5 pounds.

name: sensate
text: I think this is my favorite one ever. Well, not really, but the atmosphere is amazing. Also probably because I was awake all night waiting for it to be posted.

name: red_dawn
text: The mystery of the side dishes is revealed.

name: the_voice
text: He hides it well, but I bet Ray feels pretty let down by that.

name: achilleselbow
text: I thought cats only eat meat anyway.

name: i_love_kate
text: You wait until this point to bring this up? They don't tend to drink booze either, for the record.

name: red_dawn
text: A comment left by red_dawn was marked as spam and excluded. red_dawn: What a douche. (reported by TVsIan, Lacrimus, Magb)

name: hexjumper
text: Only in Achewood will you ever see a story told solely through a receipt.

name: pitseleh
text:
It's true. I can think of the other two times when there were awesome stories told through receipts.

Heaven's receipt

Beef's Me Day

Strangely enough, they both involve Roast Beef.

name: snoozebar
text: This one just kills me.  All that buildup to "the leaders of the army, feasting on turkey and brandy" and then you get the Safeway receipt. Genius.

name: killingthejay
text: Well they ARE expecting the man who comes in to this feast to think that $3.00 is a good price for wine.  I suppose they'd apply the same logic to turkey and brandy.  Also it is more raw to eat like a working class man.

name: cbtbone
text: There is No-Doz in the bed of the Jeep that Ray and Beef commandeer later on.

name: hollis
text: Astute!

name: catachresis
text: Beat me to it, yo. That's some good, if essentially pointless, foreshadowing in this plot here.

name: ivanstrel
text: Probably unknown to So-Rod and his begoggled companion.

name: cpnglxynchos
text: duh.

name: dougthehead
text: No side dishes, but they were nice enough to leave him a spork.

name: whuppins
text: That's an eight-and-a-half pound turkey.

name: straw
text: This speaks to the power of the GOF.  They went to a human store and bought that stuff, no underground for them

name: i_love_kate
text: If there can be animal-run Subways, why can't there be animal-run Safeways? Their names are basically the same.

name: hellabosque
text: detail...even the dang ol bakersfield zipcode.

name: timjankowiak
text: A comment left by timjankowiak was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by shogun, Firehawk, cailetshadow, BjorntD, STUART)

name: stuart
text: Late.

name: shogun
text: A comment left by shogun was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by GeyserShitdick, Wulvaine, cailetshadow, mattylite)

name: mattylite
text: Reading the comments your first time through the archive: even more lame.

name: rowboat
text:
I know I didn't. I was all, like, "What the hell are all these assholes blathering about?" [next >>]

I honestly had no idea that I would later become one of the biggest assholes among them.

name: cpnglxynchos
text: i'm glad i didn't get involved here until after i'd been up-to-speed for a time, though i then had to prove it by viewing all of them again on Assetbar.

name: heavymetaljesus
text: Man, this strip is so many different kinds of stone-cold awesome.

name: jdhenry105
text: FLUP

name: bhlaab
text: i remember so much lame speculation as to the significance fo that stupid no doz

name: boheeka
text:
Is sales tax really 8.25 in California?

yow...

name: kochipoik
text: In NZ it's 12.5%, GST. But it's included in all prices so you don't get snapped by it like in the US.

name: tellumo
text: That and you have an actual "health care system" instead of the cruel joke we have here in the US. Not that I'm bitter.

name: direhaggis
text: Y'mean people in other developed countries don't have to pay 500 bucks out-of-pocket on top of 1,000 already covered by an insurance company for a tooth extraction due to failures made by a provider working under that same insurance company? Well piss my shit.

name: soticoto
text:
Safeway is dead.
They call it all Morrisons now.

It sucks now.

name: cpnglxynchos
text: the ones i know are still called Safeway...

name: soticoto
text:
You're living in history then.
Clearly.

name: tellumo
text: I'm not sure about that, but I believe you're living in the UK. Safeway sold its UK operations to Morrisons a while ago, and they merged the two brands.

name: rowboat
text: You obviously haven't pay close enough attention to Soticoto. He honestly doesn't believe that there is land west of the Atlantic. He's funny that way.

name: cpnglxynchos
text:
i'd doubt the same way if i lived on a coast. if it's there, i should be able to SEE it.

my vacation to Hawaii was insane .

name: tellumo
text: Yeah, that was before I'd had much experience with him.

name: soticoto
text:
Well, until I saw this strip, I didn't know Safeway ever existed outside of Britain. Achewood is educational .

I suppose in hindsight, given what you've told me... I should be glad we diverged.

name: hrm
text: The names must be different depending on the region. Here in san diego all the "Safeways" are Vons, but I went up to Sacramento and Safeway was Safeway.

name: direhaggis
text:
The GoF staff put the spork there as a joke.

They know damn well that a leader will take that turkey, rip it apart at the joints and other tender places, and maw down on that dead meat until nothing but bones and an empty bottle of CB remain (and a Safeway receipt) remain. I bet when a guy decides to give turkey feasts to everyone, they put out just one spork too.

name: direhaggis
text: Or apparently as a makeshift shotglass. That is hillbilly hardcore. I should read ahead next time.

name: locust_king
text: I once worked at a Genuardi's. Safeway turkey is no good thing.

name: cpnglxynchos
text:
Safeway sporks seriously were the best kind there was. unfortunately, they no longer exist at my store.

lamz.

name: belgand
text: I'll check at one near me the next time I'm near there and if they have some, well... need a care package?

name: cpnglxynchos
text: always need a care package. also if you could pack in some cheese Ritz Bits and about three Monster energy drinks. (not pizza 'cos it would melt en route. at least a safeway gift card if you're not comfortable with sending a complete stranger food items.)

name: litfanbreastman
text: The only thing that would make this better is if it said "Rashid was your cashier today".
